speaker: OG
text: Water is a basic human right and over a billion people lack reliable access to safe drinking water.

speaker: OO
text: Not all water sources cross borders; many are contained within one country making sovereignty over water legitimate.

speaker: CG
text: An international body can eliminate political tensions, impose cooperation obligations, and mobilize significant resources for water redistribution.

speaker: CO
text: Opposition fails to provide a positive alternative to international control; voluntary regional cooperation is more effective.

speaker: OG
text: Water usage affects others downstream, limiting full sovereignty over it; basic human rights to water override strict sovereignty claims.

speaker: CO
text: Sovereignty is instrumentally valuable because it secures buy-in, explaining why countries prefer voluntary agreements like the Paris Agreement.

speaker: CG
text: Western countries have less interest in controlling African water and more incentives to cooperate to promote stability and economic allies.

speaker: CO
text: Regional, voluntary, and specific solutions tailored to local needs work better than coercive international control.

speaker: OG
text: An international body, like an arm of the UN, can allocate water budgets, mediate crises, and ensure equitable distribution.

speaker: OO
text: An international body is likely worse at managing water due to power dynamics favoring stronger countries with more allies.

speaker: CG
text: Voluntary cooperation has failed due to economic interests, political tension, sovereignty concerns, and unpopularity.

speaker: OO
text: International bodies often apply broad principles that may not fit local contexts and representatives vote based on national interests.

speaker: OG
text: Water should be managed as a global resource because it crosses borders and pollution or overuse in one country affects others.

speaker: OO
text: Sovereignty is a critical principle that should not be overridden by utilitarian arguments about water.

speaker: CG
text: Saving millions of lives outweighs sovereignty and property rights principles.

speaker: CG
text: Even if countries initially resist, they would cooperate under an international body due to incentives and long-term relations.

speaker: OG
text: Developing countries would gain power in the international body, incentivizing developed nations to regulate pollution and invest in solutions.

speaker: OO
text: International bodies lack accountability, are bureaucratic, and skewed by powerful countries influencing votes.

speaker: OO
text: World powers can use water control as leverage, turning off supplies as a coercive tool.

speaker: OG
text: International management is preferable to violent conflict over water; collaboration and sanctions are better than war.

speaker: CO
text: There is an organic sense of urgency driving voluntary regional cooperation on water, demonstrated by existing treaties.

speaker: OG
text: Examples like Israel-Syria conflicts show water disputes causing violence; international mediation can prevent this.

speaker: OO
text: Countries invest heavily in making water accessible and thus have sovereign rights over it, which an international body would undermine.

speaker: CG
text: Problems cited by opposition are mechanistic and can be solved by structuring the international body intelligently.

speaker: OO
text: Land analogy: just because land is part of a global system doesn't mean countries lose control over it; same applies to water.

speaker: CO
text: Developing countries have differing water management needs and regional interests, making unified international decisions ineffective.

speaker: CO
text: Centralized international bodies produce one-size-fits-all policies detached from local contexts, lowering policy effectiveness.

speaker: CG
text: Western bias is real but positive, as Western countries have incentives and political pressure to act responsibly regarding water.

speaker: OG
text: Hegemonies balance each other out in international law; powerful countries have incentives to be reasonable to avoid conflict and sanctions.

speaker: CO
text: Centralization reduces expert investment and accountability, increasing complacency and politicization of water management.

speaker: OO
text: Smaller countries like Ethiopia currently have some local leverage upstream that would be lost under international control.

speaker: OG
text: Economic sanctions and international law mechanisms can encourage countries to comply, even if enforcement isn't perfect.

speaker: CO
text: Regional cooperation allows tailored policies and better local knowledge than centralized international bodies.

speaker: OG
text: Experts in an international body will guide decisions, reducing purely self-interested voting by countries uninvolved in disputes.

speaker: CG
text: Water sanctions would require Security Council approval, providing checks and balances preventing abuse.

speaker: CO
text: Centralized bodies impose one-size-fits-all policies, are detached from local realities, and can politicize responsibility, reducing effectiveness.

speaker: OO
text: Populism and national interests lead representatives to prioritize domestic politics over equitable water distribution.

speaker: CO
text: In the real world, countries go to war over water due to its political sensitivity, especially in developing regions reliant on agriculture.

speaker: CG
text: Western countries have popular support and strategic incentives to promote stability and development, making them good actors.

speaker: CG
text: The debate is most relevant in Africa, where water scarcity is about distribution, political tension, lack of infrastructure, and sovereignty concerns.
